material-property-value-condition.content: You are a knowledgeable assistant specialized in recognizing and understanding named entities and their interrelations. When requested to organize information in tabular format, you are adept at filtering and presenting only the relevant and valid results. You will exclude any results that are not pertinent or are inaccurate from the table according to the discussion history.

Please analyze the following paragraph and summarize the properties, including their numerical values, of the mentioned materials.

Paragraph: The more effective quenching in the PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend than in the POBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend implies two possibilities : (i) better exciton separation in the PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend films and (ii) a larger contact area between the polymer and the PC 70 BM through more optimal nanoscale phase separation . The former could be ruled out because the PEBDTPD polymer had a slightly higher LUMO level as the POBDTPD polymer . The latter was thus mainly responsible for the effective PL quenching , as confirmed from the film morphology studies . That is , the miscibility between polymers and PC 70 BM is an important factor for efficient exciton separation . Conclusively , morphology and PL quenching studies revealed that the PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend film has more favorable features for the higher J sc . Carrier mobilities were measured to estimate the ability of hole and electron transport and the carrier mobility balance . The hole mobilities of the polymers or the polymer : PC 70 BM blends were measured via the space charge limited current (SCLC) method using hole - only devices (ITO / PEDOT : PSS / polymer or polymer : PC 70 BM / Au) . The JL 3 -V characteristics of the polymers and the polymer : PC 70 BM blend films are shown in Figure 7 . For all films , a slope of 2 in the log JL 3 - log V plot was observed , which is a signature of SCLC transport . The hole mobilities of the POBDTPD and PEBDTPD polymers were estimated to be 1.5 × 10 ^ -4 and 1.3 × 10 ^ -4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 , respectively . Although these hole mobilities of homopolymers were nearly identical , the hole mobility in the PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend film decreased only slightly to 1.2 × 10 ^ -4 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 , whereas that in the POBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend film decreased significantly to 3.5 × 10 ^ -5 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 . The considerable mobility decrease in the POBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend film may result from the less uniform , more aggregated morphology as aforementioned . In addition , the electron mobilities of the polymer : PC 70 BM blends were measured using electron - only devices (Al / polymer : PC 70 BM / Al) . The electron mobilities were 8.8 × 10 ^ -6 and 1.1 × 10 ^ -5 cm^2 V -1 s^-1 in the POBDTPD : PC 70 BM and PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blends , respectively . The hole and electron mobilities of the polymers and polymer : PC 70 BM blends are summarized in Table 3 . From this carrier mobility measurement , we concluded that the higher hole mobility of the PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blends contributed to the higher J sc values as well . Moreover , the lower FF for the PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend can be explained in terms of the balance between hole and electron transport .

Let's think step by step.

Step 1: Identify the materials mentioned in the paragraph.

- PEBDTPD
- PC 70 BM
- POBDTPD
- LUMO level
- polymers
- film morphology
- Jsc
- carrier mobilities
- hole-only devices
- ITO/PEDOT:PSS
- Au
- JL3-V characteristics
- SCLC transport
- electron-only devices
- Al

Step 2: Identify the properties and their numerical values mentioned in the paragraph.

- Quenching effectiveness: The PEBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend is more effective than the POBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend.
- Exciton separation: The PEBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend has better exciton separation.
- Contact area: The PEBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend has a larger contact area between the polymer and PC 70 BM.
- LUMO level: The PEBDTPD polymer has a slightly higher LUMO level than the POBDTPD polymer.
- PL quenching: The PEBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend has effective PL quenching.
- Miscibility: The miscibility between polymers and PC 70 BM is an important factor for efficient exciton separation.
- Morphology: The PEBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend film has more favorable morphology for higher Jsc.
- Carrier mobilities: Hole mobilities of the polymers and polymer:PC 70 BM blends were measured.
  - POBDTPD polymer: 1.5 × 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
  - PEBDTPD polymer: 1.3 × 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
  - PEBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend film: 1.2 × 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
  - POBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend film: 3.5 × 10^-5 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
- Electron mobilities: Electron mobilities of the polymer:PC 70 BM blends were measured.
  - POBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend: 8.8 × 10^-6 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
  - PEBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend: 1.1 × 10^-5 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1
- FF (fill factor): The PEBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend has a lower FF.
- Hole and electron transport balance: The lower FF for the PEBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend can be explained in terms of the balance between hole and electron transport.

Step 3: Organize the properties and their numerical values in a table.

| Property                | Numerical Value       |
|-------------------------|-----------------------|
| Quenching effectiveness | PEBDTPD:PC 70 BM > POBDTPD:PC 70 BM |
| Exciton separation      | Better in PEBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend |
| Contact area            | Larger in PEBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend |
| LUMO level              | PEBDTPD > POBDTPD       |
| PL quenching            | Effective in PEBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend |
| Miscibility             | Important for efficient exciton separation |
| Morphology              | More favorable in PEBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend film |
| Hole mobility           | POBDTPD polymer: 1.5 × 10^-4 cm^2 V^-1 s^-1 |
|                         | PEBDTPD polymer:
